Description: Body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of ram or goat to left (back, foreleg, ribs, underbelly, shoulder and trace of neck remaining; added red on neck, alternating ribs and underbelly).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University College London. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For parallels regarding the ram, see Hamburg 1897.221 by the Dodwell Painter. What remains of the forelegs suggests that the animal has relatively short legs, thus not a deer. However, see Corinth CP2034 by the Memnon Painter. Panthers and lions are depicted with their head raised.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.197) (phase 3)
